3346449220.excerpt:
The babies had been switched, of that she was sure. 
Would her own baby smell like this — like rot? Impostor. She guarded the
 truth quietly: Her real baby actually lay beneath a small, tilted 
headstone, in the graveyard near her home. The patient was a woman with 
no history of psychiatric illness.

3246323301.given_title: How the Brain Responds to Beauty
3246323301.resolved_title:
How the
 Brain Responds to Beauty
3246323301.excerpt:
Pursued by poets and artists alike, beauty is ever 
elusive. We seek it in nature, art and philosophy but also in our phones
 and furniture. We value it beyond reason, look to surround ourselves 
with it and will even lose ourselves in pursuit of it.

3146889011.resolved_title:
From fluffy to valuable: How the brain recognises
 objects
3146889011.excerpt:
To recognise a chair or a dog, our brain separates 
objects into their individual properties and then puts them back 
together. Until recently, it has remained unclear what these properties 
are.

1.caption:
The 
human brain breaks down the environment into a total of 49 properties, 
which are sufficient to categorise all objects. Depending on how similar
 the observed object is to a known category, it is then recognised as a 
dog or, for instance, a piece of furniture.

© shutterstock

3118207153.resolved_title:
The Brain Maps Out Ideas and Memories Like 
Spaces
3118207153.excerpt:
Emerging evidence suggests that the brain encodes 
abstract knowledge in the same way that it represents positions in 
space, which hints at a more universal theory of cognition.

1.caption:
In 
the parable of the blind men and the elephant, each paid attention to a 
different aspect of the creature. The brain may do something similar by 
mapping out the qualities of perceptions, experiences and abstract 
concepts along various dimensions, with the help of the same system that
 it uses to map out physical spaces. Credit: Alexandre Tamisier for 
Quanta Magazine.

3.caption:
This
 post originally appeared on Quanta Magazine and was published January 
1, 2019. This article is republished here with permission.Get math and 
science news, explainers, interviews and more in your inbox.Get Quanta’s
 weekly newsletter

3140651372.given_title:
Visual Perception: How we perceive graphical 
information
3140651372.excerpt:
Why do we visualize data? It helps us to comprehend huge
 amounts of data by compressing it into a simple, easy to understand 
visualization. It helps us to find hidden patterns or see underlying 
problems in the data itself which might not have been obvious without a 
good chart.

3115788429.resolved_title:
Your Brain Chooses What to Let 
You See
3115788429.excerpt:
Beneath our awareness, the brain lets certain kinds of 
stimuli automatically capture our attention by lowering the priority of 
the rest.

1.caption:
An 
osprey can zero in on an unassuming trout, even amid distracting sensory
 information such as the motion of the river’s current. This ability is 
due in part to automatic filtering mechanisms hard-wired in the brain. 
Photo by Jeff J Mitchell / Staff / Getty Images.

as shown in the wheel 
on the left
2.caption:
What’s in a Name?: When shown a wheel of 
similarly colored squares, people identify the offbeat shade more 
quickly if it comes from a different color category

3.caption:
Baby
 Blues: In laboratory tests, psychologists have found that babies tend 
to stare longer at colors that from categories they haven’t seen before,
 suggesting that our ability to perceive boundaries between colors may 
exist as early as infancy. Photo courtesy of Sussex Baby Lab.

lot of layers here.

2648168911.resolved_title: Gustav Klimt in the Brain Lab
2648168911.excerpt: What is neuroscience doing to art?

2.caption:
Your Brain on Klimt:
 Our brains assemble Gustav Klimt’s
 paintings piece by piece, symbol by 
symbol, tricking us into sensing 
the beauty of the whole, Eric Kandel 
says. Gustav Klimt

3.caption:
Interiors: 
Oskar Kokoschka painted emotional states 
more than people, Eric Kandel 
says. “He painted them with an idea of 
getting inside their heads.” Oskar Kokoschka

5.caption:
The Two Cultures: In a 2018 interview, Eric Kandel says, 
“I don’t think art and science are that far apart because both are 
playing all the time to make sure they’ve got it right.”

6.caption:
Hunger Artist:
 “Egon Schiele is the Kafka of painting,”
 Eric Kandel says. “He thought 
he could communicate emotions most 
effectively using his own naked 
body.”Egon Schiele

2535685198.excerpt:
Neuroscience has found that gestures are not merely 
important as tools of expression but as guides of cognition and 
perception. Remember the last time someone flipped you the bird? Whether
 or not that single finger was accompanied by spoken obscenities, you 
knew exactly what it meant.
